Welcome to \sphinxcode{mleap} (Machine Learning Experiments Automation Package).


\chapter{Description of the project}
\label{\detokenize{project::doc}}\label{\detokenize{project:welcome-to-mleap-s-documentation}}\label{\detokenize{project:description-of-the-project}}
The goal of \sphinxcode{mleap} is to automate the workflow for training and comparing machine learning estimators. The package facilitates the training of a large number of estimators on multiple datasets. It also provides a statistical framework for comparing the performance of the trained estimators.


\section{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{project:overview}}
\sphinxcode{mleap} seeks to expand the functionality of the \sphinxhref{http://scikit-learn.org}{scikit-learn} package. It also aims at providing a seamless integration with other packages such as \sphinxhref{https://www.scipy.org/}{scipy}, \sphinxhref{https://www.statsmodels.org}{statsmodels} and \sphinxhref{https://github.com/maximtrp/scikit-posthocs}{scikit-posthocs}.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
Knowledge of all above mentioned packages is not necessarily required in order to work with \sphinxcode{mleap}. However, in order to make full use of it and be able to expand its functionality understanding of \sphinxhref{http://scikit-learn.org}{scikit-learn} is highly desirable.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\sphinxcode{mleap} is comprised of the following main modules.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
{\hyperref[\detokenize{estimators:estimators}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Estimators}}}}

\item {} 
{\hyperref[\detokenize{data:data}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Data}}}}

\item {} 
{\hyperref[\detokenize{experiments:experiments}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Experiments}}}}

\item {} 
{\hyperref[\detokenize{analyze_results:analyze-results}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Analyze Results}}}}

\item {} 
{\hyperref[\detokenize{shared:shared}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Shared}}}}

\end{itemize}

The graph below shows on a high level the interaction between the modules.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics[scale=0.5]{{classes}.png}
\end{figure}

The user should begin by saving the preprocessed datasets on its hard drive. The \sphinxcode{Data} module is then evoked for saving the datasets in a HDF5 database. The second step of the process is to instantiate the machine learning estimator objects. The user has the choice of either using the pre-defined estimators in the \sphinxcode{Estimators} module or defining its own by making use of the {\hyperref[\detokenize{estimators:mleap-estimator-label}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{mleap\_estimator}}}}. Once this step is completed the user can proceed to running the experiments by making use of the \sphinxcode{Orchestrator} module. Once all estimators are trained on all datasets the user can carry out the final step of analyzing the results by evoking the \sphinxcode{Analuze results} module. The \sphinxcode{Shared} module provides an interface for reading and writing files as well as for accessing the HDF5 database files and is used by all other modules. This module can also be directly accessed by the end user.


\chapter{Tutorial}
\label{\detokenize{tutorial:tutorial}}\label{\detokenize{tutorial::doc}}
The code below will help you get started with mleap.

The following Jupyter Notebook contains the code used below.

\sphinxcode{mleap.ipynb}.


\section{Data Preprocessing and Estimator Training Phase}
\label{\detokenize{tutorial:data-preprocessing-and-estimator-training-phase}}
\sphinxstylestrong{1. Get your data.}

The included code downloads preprocessed datasets from the UCI Machine Learning Repository and stores them locally.

\sphinxcode{delgado\_datasets.py}

The enclosed code can be used as follows:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{delgado} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{DownloadAndConvertDelgadoDatasets}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{datasets}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{metadata} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{delgado}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{download\PYGZus{}and\PYGZus{}extract\PYGZus{}datasets}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{verbose} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb+bp}{False}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxstylestrong{2. Define Input and Output HDF5 objects.}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{input\PYGZus{}io} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{open\PYGZus{}hdf5}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data/delgado.hdf5}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{mode}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{a}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{out\PYGZus{}io} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{open\PYGZus{}hdf5}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data/classification.hdf5}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{mode}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{a}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxstylestrong{3. Store your data in HDF5 database.}

Once the datasets are stored locally we put them in an HDF5 database.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pandas\PYGZus{}to\PYGZus{}db}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{save\PYGZus{}loc\PYGZus{}hdf5}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{delgado\PYGZus{}datasets/}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} 
                  \PYG{n}{datasets}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{datasets}\PYG{p}{,} 
                  \PYG{n}{dts\PYGZus{}metadata}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{metadata}\PYG{p}{,} 
                  \PYG{n}{save\PYGZus{}loc\PYGZus{}hdd}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data/delgado.hdf5}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)} 
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxstylestrong{4. Split the data in test and train sets.}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{dts\PYGZus{}names\PYGZus{}list}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{dts\PYGZus{}names\PYGZus{}list\PYGZus{}full\PYGZus{}path} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{list\PYGZus{}datasets}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{hdf5\PYGZus{}io}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{input\PYGZus{}io}\PYG{p}{,} 
                                           \PYG{n}{hdf5\PYGZus{}group}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{delgado\PYGZus{}datasets/}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{split\PYGZus{}dts\PYGZus{}list} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{split\PYGZus{}datasets}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{hdf5\PYGZus{}in}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{input\PYGZus{}io}\PYG{p}{,} 
                                     \PYG{n}{hdf5\PYGZus{}out}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{out\PYGZus{}io}\PYG{p}{,} 
                                     \PYG{n}{dataset\PYGZus{}paths}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{dts\PYGZus{}names\PYGZus{}list\PYGZus{}full\PYGZus{}path}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxstylestrong{5. Instantiate estimator objects and the experiments orchestrator class.}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{instantiated\PYGZus{}models} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{instantiate\PYGZus{}default\PYGZus{}estimators}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{estimators}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{all}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{orchest} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Orchestrator}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{hdf5\PYGZus{}input\PYGZus{}io}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{input\PYGZus{}io}\PYG{p}{,} 
                      \PYG{n}{hdf5\PYGZus{}output\PYGZus{}io}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{out\PYGZus{}io}\PYG{p}{,} 
                      \PYG{n}{dts\PYGZus{}names}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{dts\PYGZus{}names\PYGZus{}list}\PYG{p}{,}
                      \PYG{n}{original\PYGZus{}datasets\PYGZus{}group\PYGZus{}h5\PYGZus{}path}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{delgado\PYGZus{}datasets/}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxstylestrong{6. Run the experiments.}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{orchest}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{run}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{modelling\PYGZus{}strategies}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{instantiated\PYGZus{}models}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

At this point mleap will train all instantiated estimators on all datasets that were passed to the constructor. The trained models will be saved on the disk.

After this process is finished we can make predictions on the test sets using the trained estimators. in the previous step.

\sphinxstylestrong{7. Make predictions on the test sets.}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{orchest}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{predict\PYGZus{}all}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{trained\PYGZus{}models\PYGZus{}dir}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data/trained\PYGZus{}models}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{estimators}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{instantiated\PYGZus{}models}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\section{Analyze Results of Machine Learning Experiments Phase}
\label{\detokenize{tutorial:analyze-results-of-machine-learning-experiments-phase}}
After the training phase is completed the user can use the predictions on the test sets to run statistical tests.

The starting point is to calculate the prediction error achieved on the test sets. Two main methods are available for this purpose:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{mleap.analyze\_results.analyze\_results.calculate\_error\_all\_datasets()}. This method calculates the error achieved by each estimator on each of the datasets and returns the results in a dictionary format.

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{mleap.analyze\_results.analyze\_results.calculate\_error\_per\_dataset()}. This method calculates the prediction error for each estimator on each datapoint for each dataset.

\end{itemize}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{analyze} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{AnalyseResults}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{hdf5\PYGZus{}output\PYGZus{}io}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{out\PYGZus{}io}\PYG{p}{,} 
                        \PYG{n}{hdf5\PYGZus{}input\PYGZus{}io}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{input\PYGZus{}io}\PYG{p}{,} 
                        \PYG{n}{input\PYGZus{}h5\PYGZus{}original\PYGZus{}datasets\PYGZus{}group}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{delgado\PYGZus{}datasets/}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} 
                        \PYG{n}{output\PYGZus{}h5\PYGZus{}predictions\PYGZus{}group}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{experiments/predictions/}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{error\PYGZus{}all\PYGZus{}datasets} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{analyze}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{calculate\PYGZus{}error\PYGZus{}all\PYGZus{}datasets}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{metric}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{mean\PYGZus{}squared\PYGZus{}error}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{error\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}dataset}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{error\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}dataset\PYGZus{}df} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{analyze}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{calculate\PYGZus{}error\PYGZus{}per\PYGZus{}dataset}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{metric}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{mean\PYGZus{}squared\PYGZus{}error}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

The output of these two functions can be used as an input to the flowing methods tests:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{mleap.analyze\_results.analyze\_results.calculate\_average\_std()}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{mleap.analyze\_results.analyze\_results.cohens\_d()}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{mleap.analyze\_results.analyze\_results.t\_test()}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{mleap.analyze\_results.analyze\_results.sign\_test()}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{mleap.analyze\_results.analyze\_results.t\_test\_with\_bonferroni\_correction()}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{mleap.analyze\_results.analyze\_results.wilcoxon\_test()}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{mleap.analyze\_results.analyze\_results.friedman\_test()}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{mleap.analyze\_results.analyze\_results.nemenyi()}

\end{itemize}

Please refer to {\hyperref[\detokenize{analyze_results:analyze-results}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Analyze Results}}}} for additional information about their use.


\section{Defining Estimators}
\label{\detokenize{tutorial:defining-estimators}}
\sphinxcode{mleap} comes with a number of built-in estimators. However, the user also has the flexibility to define its own by inehriting from the {\hyperref[\detokenize{estimators:mleap-estimator-label}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{mleap\_estimator}}}} class. The user should at a minimum implement the \sphinxcode{save()} and \sphinxcode{build()} methods. Please refer to one of the implemented {\hyperref[\detokenize{estimators:estimators}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Estimators}}}} for additional information.


\chapter{Modules}
\label{\detokenize{modules:modules}}\label{\detokenize{modules::doc}}

\section{Estimators}
\label{\detokenize{estimators:estimators}}\label{\detokenize{estimators::doc}}\label{\detokenize{estimators:id1}}

\subsection{bayes\_estimators}
\label{\detokenize{estimators:bayes-estimators}}\label{\detokenize{estimators:module-mleap.estimators.bayes_estimators}}\index{mleap.estimators.bayes\_estimators (module)}\index{Bernoulli\_Naive\_Bayes (class in mleap.estimators.bayes\_estimators)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{estimators:mleap.estimators.bayes_estimators.Bernoulli_Naive_Bayes}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{class }\sphinxcode{mleap.estimators.bayes\_estimators.}\sphinxbfcode{Bernoulli\_Naive\_Bayes}}{\emph{wrapped}, \emph{wrapper}, \emph{enabled=None}}{}

\section{Experiments}
\label{\detokenize{experiments:id1}}\label{\detokenize{experiments::doc}}\label{\detokenize{experiments:experiments}}
This module orchestrates the process of training the estimators on the datasets. It contains two main loops: over all estimators and over all datasets.


\subsection{orchestrator}
\label{\detokenize{experiments:module-mleap.experiments.orchestrator}}\label{\detokenize{experiments:orchestrator}}\index{mleap.experiments.orchestrator (module)}\index{Orchestrator (class in mleap.experiments.orchestrator)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{experiments:mleap.experiments.orchestrator.Orchestrator}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{class }\sphinxcode{mleap.experiments.orchestrator.}\sphinxbfcode{Orchestrator}}{\emph{hdf5\_input\_io}, \emph{hdf5\_output\_io}, \emph{dts\_names}, \emph{original\_datasets\_group\_h5\_path}, \emph{experiments\_predictions\_group='experiments/predictions'}, \emph{experiments\_trained\_models\_dir='data/trained\_models'}}{}
Bases: \sphinxcode{object}

Orchestrates the sequencing of running the machine learning experiments.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{hdf5\_input\_io} ({\hyperref[\detokenize{shared:mleap.shared.files_io.FilesIO}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{FilesIO()}}}}) \textendash{} instance of {\hyperref[\detokenize{shared:mleap.shared.files_io.FilesIO}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{FilesIO()}}}} with reference to the input file

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{hdf5\_output\_io} ({\hyperref[\detokenize{shared:mleap.shared.files_io.FilesIO}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{FilesIO()}}}}) \textendash{} instance of {\hyperref[\detokenize{shared:mleap.shared.files_io.FilesIO}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{FilesIO()}}}} with reference to the output file

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{dts\_names} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{array of strings}) \textendash{} array with the names of the datasets on which experiments will be run.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{experiments\_predictions\_group} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{string}) \textendash{} path in HDF5 database where predictions will be saved

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{experiments\_trained\_models\_dir} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{string}) \textendash{} folder on disk where trained estimators will be saved.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}
\index{predict\_all() (mleap.experiments.orchestrator.Orchestrator method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{experiments:mleap.experiments.orchestrator.Orchestrator.predict_all}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{predict\_all}}{\emph{trained\_models\_dir}, \emph{estimators}}{}
Make predictions on test sets
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{trained\_models\_dir} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{string}) \textendash{} directory where the trained models are saved

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{estimators} (array of {\hyperref[\detokenize{estimators:mleap-estimator-label}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{mleap\_estimator}}}} objects) \textendash{} {\hyperref[\detokenize{estimators:mleap-estimator-label}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{mleap\_estimator}}}} objects. The trained models are set as a property to the object.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{run() (mleap.experiments.orchestrator.Orchestrator method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{experiments:mleap.experiments.orchestrator.Orchestrator.run}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{run}}{\emph{modelling\_strategies}}{}
Main module for training the estimators. 
The inputs of the function are:
\begin{enumerate}
\item {} 
The input and output databse files containing the datasets.

\item {} 
The instantiated estimators.

\end{enumerate}

The method iterates through all datasets in the input database file 
and trains all modelling strategies on these datasets. At the end of the process 
we make predictions on the test sets and store them in the output database file.

The class uses helper methods in the experiments class to avoid too many nested loops.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{modelling\_strategies} (array of {\hyperref[\detokenize{estimators:mleap-estimator-label}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{mleap\_estimator}}}} objects) \textendash{} array of estimators that will be used for training

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}


\end{fulllineitems}



\section{Data}
\label{\detokenize{data:id1}}\label{\detokenize{data::doc}}\label{\detokenize{data:data}}
Contains interface methods for certain {\hyperref[\detokenize{shared:files-io-label}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{files\_io}}}} methods.


\subsection{data}
\label{\detokenize{data:id2}}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{data:module-mleap.data.data}}\index{mleap.data.data (module)}\index{Data (class in mleap.data.data)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{data:mleap.data.data.Data}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{class }\sphinxcode{mleap.data.data.}\sphinxbfcode{Data}}{\emph{experiments\_predictions\_group='experiments/predictions'}, \emph{split\_datasets\_group='split\_dts\_idx'}, \emph{train\_idx='train\_idx'}, \emph{test\_idx='test\_idx'}}{}

\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}

\item {}

\item {}

\section{Analyze Results}
\label{\detokenize{analyze_results:analyze-results}}\label{\detokenize{analyze_results::doc}}\label{\detokenize{analyze_results:id1}}
This modules contains methods for analyzing the results produced by the trained estimators and benchmarking their performance.

\index{cohens\_d() (mleap.analyze\_results.analyze\_results.AnalyseResults method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{analyze_results:mleap.analyze_results.analyze_results.AnalyseResults.cohens_d}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{cohens\_d}}{\emph{estimator\_dict}}{}
Cohen’s d is an effect size used to indicate the standardised difference
between two means. The calculation is implemented natively (without the 
use of third-party libraries). More information can be found here:
\sphinxhref{https://en.wikiversity.org/wiki/Cohen\%27s\_d}{Cohen’s d}.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{estimator\_dict} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{dictionary}) \textendash{} dictionay with keys \sphinxtitleref{names of estimators} and 
values \sphinxtitleref{errors achieved by estimators on test datasets}.

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
pandas DataFrame.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{friedman\_test() (mleap.analyze\_results.analyze\_results.AnalyseResults method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{analyze_results:mleap.analyze_results.analyze_results.AnalyseResults.friedman_test}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{friedman\_test}}{\emph{observations}}{}
The Friedman test is a non-parametric statistical test used to detect differences 
in treatments across multiple test attempts. The procedure involves ranking each row (or block) together, 
then considering the values of ranks by columns.
Implementation used: \sphinxhref{https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy-0.15.1/reference/generated/scipy.stats.friedmanchisquare.html}{scipy.stats}.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{observations} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{dictionary}) \textendash{} Dictionary with errors on test sets achieved by estimators.

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
tuple of dictionary, pandas DataFrame.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{nemenyi() (mleap.analyze\_results.analyze\_results.AnalyseResults method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{analyze_results:mleap.analyze_results.analyze_results.AnalyseResults.nemenyi}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{nemenyi}}{\emph{obeservations}}{}
Post-hoc test run if the \sphinxtitleref{friedman\_test} reveals statistical significance.
For more information see \sphinxhref{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nemenyi\_test}{Nemenyi test}.
Implementation used \sphinxhref{https://github.com/maximtrp/scikit-posthocs}{scikit-posthocs}.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{observations} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{dictionary}) \textendash{} Dictionary with errors on test sets achieved by estimators.

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
pandas DataFrame.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{sign\_test() (mleap.analyze\_results.analyze\_results.AnalyseResults method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{analyze_results:mleap.analyze_results.analyze_results.AnalyseResults.sign_test}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{sign\_test}}{\emph{observations}}{}
Non-parametric test for testing consistent differences between pairs of obeservations.
The test counts the number of observations that are greater, smaller and equal to the mean
\sphinxurl{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sign\_test}.

\sphinxhref{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilcoxon\_signed-rank\_test}{Wilcoxon signed-rank test}.
Tests whether two  related paired samples come from the same distribution.

\section{Shared}
\label{\detokenize{shared:shared}}\label{\detokenize{shared::doc}}\label{\detokenize{shared:id1}}
This module provides functionality that is used in the other modules. It contains prodominantly interface methods for working with HDF5 databases as well as mehtods for manipulating files on the hard drive.

\index{save\_array\_hdf5() (mleap.shared.files\_io.FilesIO method)}

Saves an array of data to HDF5 database

:type group:string
:param group: path to group in HDF5 where the arrays will be saved
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{datasets} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{array of arrays}) \textendash{} array in the form {[}{[}x\_1{]},{[}x\_2{]},…{[}x\_n{]}{]} representing the data that will be saved. Each x\_i is saved
in a different sub-group under the common parent HDF5 group.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{array\_names} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{array of strings}) \textendash{} name of sub-groups where the dataset arrays will be saved

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{array\_meta} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{array of dictionaries}) \textendash{} metadata for each sub-group

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}
